hobby.message: Still folding origami to stay grounded?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: I’m fine. Just tired, that’s all.
Was out with my camera again, city’s been strange.
Streets aren’t as lively for photos lately.
Doesn’t feel the same since that official died.
I’m alright. Just frustrated, really.
Went shooting film early. Hard getting good shots these days.
Security’s been tight since Halden died.
Makes it risky, hauling real cameras.
Feels like every lens is being watched, not just mine.
I’m okay, just decompressing from this morning.
Spent hours taking street photos with my analog camera.
After Halden’s death, the city’s off-balance—like even the light is nervous.
Film’s hard to get now, but I still sneak a roll when I can.
Miss the old rhythms, people are so wary lately.
Sometimes I wonder if I’ll have anywhere safe to develop these shots.
Honestly, the city wore me out today.
I shoot street photography with actual 35mm film—illegal to buy, but I manage.
With Halden gone, everything feels unmoored. People keep their heads down, even trams pause odd places.
I photographed an entire block and barely caught a real smile.
Used to be, folks didn’t mind a picture; now they dodge like I’m holding a gun.
Feels like the city’s being drained of color.
I’ll risk a low BCI score if it means keeping something real.
Yeah, I’m here to clear my head after a strange shoot.
I’m obsessed with street photography—real analog film, not state-filtered feeds.
Smuggled film costs me a fortune and nearly cost me my job twice.
Today was the first time I noticed the city truly pausing—because Halden’s dead, nobody says it, but everyone moves different.
The BCI’s already flagged me for ‘suspicious activity’ just for developing rolls at home.
I caught the feeling on film, but it wasn’t the moment I wanted—just the silence afterward.
Sometimes I wonder if these photos are the last pieces of Stenograd before the system erases our edges.
If I disappear, check under the floorboards—I always stash the negatives.
hobby_answer: Yeah, it does.
Film doesn’t adjust for propaganda. It just shows what’s there.
Lately, the city’s been jumpy. Halden’s death, you know.
Hard to even get a clear shot when systems are this slow.
That’s all I’ll say.
It does, actually.
Analog lets me freeze a moment before it’s re-written by the system.
I noticed delays out there after Halden—the gates, the trams.
Makes it harder to catch good shots, people are restless.
Feels like the city’s holding its breath for the next update.
Taking photos in this mess is something else.
Absolutely. Analog film strips away the filters—literal and figurative.
With Halden gone, you see the city’s nerves in every corner.
I tried a street shoot last week; crowd patterns are different.
People hesitate at crossings now, waiting for system pings.
Some spots are just emptier—like everyone’s avoiding being seen.
Even the developing process feels riskier—lab times are crawling.
Every frame’s a snapshot of uncertainty, these days.
Definitely. You see things analog that digital would hide—or erase.
After Halden’s death, routines are broken. Streets go quiet without warning.
Caught a delivery courier frozen by a system glitch yesterday. Totally surreal.
It’s subtle, but people act like they’re being watched even more.
Processing film takes forever now. Lab’s backlog started right after the system glitched.
Last roll, I waited two weeks for prints—staff said nothing worked as usual.
Some of my best shots lately are of empty places, which never used to be empty.
You sense everyone’s just… waiting for the next shoe to drop.
Yeah. Film’s as close to truth as you get in this city.
My father ran BCI patrol—he warned me how things can vanish overnight.
Now, Halden’s gone and even simple routines are unpredictable. Feels like the city lost its balance.
On Friday, I tried to photograph the morning shift by Tower 9—nothing moved right.
People linger, stare at sensors, avoid crossing streets too soon.
My BCI score dipped from lingering in wrong zones with my camera.
Leftover warnings in my profile. Even the photo lab flagged my order for review.
I stash my negatives in different places—system’s more likely to flag the real moments now.
Best shot I got was of a woman looking straight at a dead sensor—like she knew.
